) This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section provides guidance on campus support procedures related to examinations of partnerships subject to provi- sions of Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA). (

) Purpose: This handbook describes: • Limits on ﬁling an Administrative Adjustment Request (AAR); • Selection and classiﬁcation of AARs; • Campus Pass-through Function (CPF) procedures for non-selected cases; • CPF procedures for linked ﬁeld controlled AARs; • Feild procedures for AARs; • TEFRA Technical Services responibilities; • Petitioned AARs; • Real Estate Mortgage Investment Conduit (REMIC) and AARs; and • Erroneous refund procedures. (

) Audience: Field examination Revenue Agents (RAs) and campus RAs, Tax Compliance Officers (TCOs), Tax Examiners (TEs) and Clerks working pass- through entities and/or their investors linked on the Pass-through Control System (PCS) (formerly the Partnership Control System). (
) Policy Owner: Director, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), Headquar- ters, Examination - Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP). (
) Program Owner: Program Manager, Campus Examination and Field (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS). (
) Primary Stakeholders: Small Business/ Self Employed, Large Business International (LB&I), and Appeals. (

) Program Goals: Establish an electronic linkage between the partnership examined and its underlying partners in order to generate notices required statute, monitor and control statutes, and gather closing information. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
I, Providing Feedback About an IRM Section -Outside of Clearance. (
) TEFRA was passed in

to allow examinations and statutes to be con- trolled at the partnership level. This eliminated the need to control each individual partner statute. It also uniﬁed the litigation process whereby the nership ﬁles the petition rather than each individual partner. The PCS was created to establish an electronic linkage between the partnerships and their underlying partners. This helps ensure that all partners, no matter how complex the partnership structure, are sent notices and adjusted in a timely manner. PCS linkage allows the campus to work those partners so the examiner can focus on partnership examinations. PCS also allows the to systemically generate notices, control statutes, and gather closing tion. (
) For partnerships subject to the TEFRA uniﬁed partnership audit and litigation procedures, Internal Revenue Code (IRC)

establishes the ability for a Matters Partner (TMP) to ﬁle an AAR to change its treatment of a item reported on the partnership return to the treatment requested on the Additionally, any non-pass-through partner may ﬁle an AAR on their own Internal Revenue Manual

TEFRA was passed in

to allow examinations and statutes to be con- trolled at the partnership level. This eliminated the need to control each individual partner statute. It also uniﬁed the litigation process whereby the nership ﬁles the petition rather than each individual partner. The PCS was created to establish an electronic linkage between the partnerships and their underlying partners. This helps ensure that all partners, no matter how complex the partnership structure, are sent notices and adjusted in a timely manner. PCS linkage allows the campus to work those partners so the examiner can focus on partnership examinations. PCS also allows the campus to systemically generate notices, control statutes, and gather closing informa- tion. Generally, any ad- justments to partnership items that will result in refunds must be raised in a Final Partnership Administrative Adjustment (FPAA) or petition to an FPAA or be forever barred. ) Middle tier (any pass-through entity as deﬁned by IRC

)) amended returns requesting adjustments for pass-through partnership items from a source partnership cannot bind their partners and are not considered AARs. Processing a middle tier amended return as an AAR may result in erroneous refunds or assessments. Middle tier amended returns reﬂecting only pass- through adjustments should not be processed or suspended and should be returned to ﬁles. The pass-through adjustments may be processed on those middle tier returns when a ﬁnal determination is made on the AAR from the adjustments originate. (

) The Director, SB/SE, Examination, Headquarters, Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP) is responsible for: a. Coordinating and implementing TEFRA policy changes; b. Coordinating resolutions for TEFRA related problems; and c. Updating this Handbook. (

) The SB/SE Program Manager, Examination Field and Campus Policy, Exam and Field Support (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS) is responsible for: a. Ensuring that TEFRA procedural changes and computer program changes are implemented and coordinated with area office and campus examination personnel; and b. Monitoring and evaluating area office and campus examination PCS quality control procedures. (
) Field Territory Managers, Field Area Directors, Director over LB&I Ogden and Director, Examination - Brookhaven, are responsible for ensuring that TEFRA policies and procedures are followed. (
) Field Examination Managers and Campus Field Support Operations are responsible for: a. Maintaining an updated copy of IRM

, Partnership Control System (PCS) Handbook, in their respective functions; b. Ensuring the training of technical and clerical employees in TEFRA pro- cedures; and c. Establishing PCS records and acting on PCS reports in a timely to assure an accurate PCS database. (
) The Campus TEFRA/Pass-Through Coordinator works with: • The other TEFRA coordinator(s) • Their local employees • Other campus functional areas to ensure timely processing of TEFRA related returns (
) The campus PCS Coordinator is charged with: • Identifying and resolving technical problems • Identifying and coordinating the resolution of PCS systemic problems (

) Following are speciﬁc Campus TEFRA/Pass-Through Coordinator ties: a. Coordinate with campus and ﬁeld pass-through coordinators on case cessing issues; b. Coordinate with Headquarters on any legal issues that need to be addressed by Chief Counsel; c. Review closing packages for completeness; d. Provide technical support to employees. ) When a partner ﬁles an AAR, the service has four options for processing the request (IRC

(d)): a. The request can be treated as a normal claim for nonpartnership b. The Service may assess an additional tax that would result from the requested adjustments; c. The Service can mail to the partner a notice that all partnership items the partner for the taxable year to which it relates will be treated as partnership items; or d. The Service may conduct a partnership proceeding. (

) In general, if the ﬁeld receives an amended TEFRA partner return, the ﬁeld follow option (d) and open the related TEFRA entity for examination and determinations as to the validity of the request. TEFRA Procedures speciﬁed IRM
